question_stem: The curve \(y = 2x^2 + px + 5\), where \(p\) is a real constant, lies entirely above the x-axis.

parts.question_text: Find the set of possible values of \(p\), giving your answer in surd form.
parts.solution_text:
Since the curve lies entirely above the x-axis, the quadratic equation \(2x^2 + px + 5 = 0\) has no real roots. Therefore, the discriminant must be negative.

Discriminant, \(\Delta = b^2 - 4ac\)
\(\Delta = p^2 - 4(2)(5) = p^2 - 40\)

For no real roots, \(\Delta < 0\):
\(p^2 - 40 < 0\)
\(p^2 < 40\)
\(-\sqrt{40} < p < \sqrt{40}\)
\(-2\sqrt{10} < p < 2\sqrt{10}\)
